content.question:
Directions: For parts of the free-response question that require calculations, clearly show the method used and the steps involved in arriving at your answers. You must show your work to receive credit for your answer. Examples and equations may be included in your answers where appropriate.

<math alttext="B P B aqueous, which is blue, plus H 2 O with a positive one charge aqueous, is in equilibrium with H B P B with a positive one charge aqueous, which is yellow, plus H 2 O liquid" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtable><mtr><mtd><mtext>BPB</mtext><mrow><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>+</mo><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><msup><mrow><mtext>O</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>⇄</mo><msup><mrow><mtext>HPBP</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>+</mo><mtext></mtext><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mtext>O</mtext><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>l</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow></mrow></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd columnalign="left"><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.8em"></mspace><mi>b</mi><mi>l</mi><mi>u</mi><mi>e</mi><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="9.2em"></mspace><mi>y</mi><mi>e</mi><mi>l</mi><mi>l</mi><mi>o</mi><mi>w</mi></mtd></mtr></mtable></mrow></mstyle></math>

Bromophenol blue, <math alttext="B P B" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>BP</mtext><mtext>B</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, is a blue dye whose spectrum has a strong absorption peak at a wavelength of <math alttext="590 nanometers" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>590</mn><mo>⁢</mo><mtext> </mtext><mtext>nm</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>. <math alttext="B P B" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>B</mtext><mtext>PB</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> reacts with hydronium ions according to the equation above, producing water and <math alttext="H B P B with a positive one charge" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>H</mtext><mtext>B</mtext><mtext>P</mtext><msup><mrow><mtext>B</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math>, which is yellow and has a strong absorption peak at a wavelength of <math alttext="440 nanometers" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>440</mn><mtext> </mtext><mtext>nm</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>.

(a) Write the <math alttext="K sub e q" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>K</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>e</mi><mi>q</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> expression for the equilibrium reaction above.The absorption spectra of an equilibrium mixture of <math alttext="B P B aqueous" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>BP</mtext><mtext>B</mtext><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="H B P B with a positive one charge aqueous" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>H</mtext><mtext>BP</mtext><msup><mrow><mtext>B</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> , collected at two different temperatures, are shown in the following diagram.

frqParts.text:
Directions: For parts of the free-response question that require calculations, clearly show the method used and the steps involved in arriving at your answers. You must show your work to receive credit for your answer. Examples and equations may be included in your answers where appropriate.

<math alttext="B P B aqueous, which is blue, plus H 2 O with a positive one charge aqueous, is in equilibrium with H B P B with a positive one charge aqueous, which is yellow, plus H 2 O liquid" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtable><mtr><mtd><mtext>BPB</mtext><mrow><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>+</mo><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><msup><mrow><mtext>O</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>⇄</mo><msup><mrow><mtext>HPBP</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>+</mo><mtext></mtext><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mtext>O</mtext><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>l</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow></mrow></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd columnalign="left"><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.8em"></mspace><mi>b</mi><mi>l</mi><mi>u</mi><mi>e</mi><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="9.2em"></mspace><mi>y</mi><mi>e</mi><mi>l</mi><mi>l</mi><mi>o</mi><mi>w</mi></mtd></mtr></mtable></mrow></mstyle></math>

Bromophenol blue, <math alttext="B P B" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>BP</mtext><mtext>B</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, is a blue dye whose spectrum has a strong absorption peak at a wavelength of <math alttext="590 nanometers" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>590</mn><mo>⁢</mo><mtext> </mtext><mtext>nm</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>. <math alttext="B P B" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>B</mtext><mtext>PB</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> reacts with hydronium ions according to the equation above, producing water and <math alttext="H B P B with a positive one charge" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>H</mtext><mtext>B</mtext><mtext>P</mtext><msup><mrow><mtext>B</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math>, which is yellow and has a strong absorption peak at a wavelength of <math alttext="440 nanometers" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>440</mn><mtext> </mtext><mtext>nm</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>.

(a) Write the <math alttext="K sub e q" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>K</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>e</mi><mi>q</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> expression for the equilibrium reaction above.The absorption spectra of an equilibrium mixture of <math alttext="B P B aqueous" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>BP</mtext><mtext>B</mtext><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="H B P B with a positive one charge aqueous" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>H</mtext><mtext>BP</mtext><msup><mrow><mtext>B</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> , collected at two different temperatures, are shown in the following diagram.

(b) Which peak, the one at <math alttext="440 nanometers" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>440</mn><mtext> </mtext><mtext>nm</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> or the one at <math alttext="590 nanometers" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>590</mn><mtext> </mtext><mtext>nm</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, results from the absorption of photons with the greater energy? Justify your answer.
(c) Based on the diagram above, is the forward reaction endothermic or exothermic? Justify your answer in terms of Le Châtelier’s principle.

A calibration plot of the absorbance at wavelength <math alttext="590 nanometers" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>590</mn><mtext> </mtext><mtext>nm</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> versus the concentration of <math alttext="B P B" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>B</mtext><mtext>PB</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> is shown in the graph below.

(d) Based on the best-fit line shown in the graph, what is the approximate absorbance of a solution in which <math alttext="the molar concentration of BPB equals 3.5 times 10 to the negative 5, molar" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mo stretchy="false">[</mo><mtext>B</mtext><mtext>PB</mtext><mo stretchy="false">]</mo><mo>=</mo><mn>3.5</mn><mo>×</mo><msup><mrow><mn>10</mn></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>5</mn></mrow></msup><mtext> </mtext><mi>M</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> ?

(e) A student measures the absorbance of a <math alttext="B P B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>BP</mtext><mtext>B</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> solution of unknown concentration in order to determine the <math alttext="molar concentration of B P B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mo stretchy="false">[</mo><mtext>B</mtext><mtext>P</mtext><mtext>B</mtext><mo stretchy="false">]</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> in the solution using the calibration plot above. If a fingerprint remains on the cuvette and in the path of light in the spectrophotometer during the measurement, what would be the effect on the estimated molarity of <math alttext="B P B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>B</mtext><mtext>PB</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>? Explain your reasoning.

Over time, <math alttext="B P B" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>B</mtext><mtext>PB</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> converts to a colorless molecule in the presence of <math alttext="O H with a negative one charge" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>O</mtext><msup><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math> ions. To study the rate of the reaction, the student recorded the absorbance of the <math alttext="B P B" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>BP</mtext><mtext>B</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> solution at <math alttext="590 nanometers" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>590</mn><mtext> </mtext><mtext>nm</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> in a <math alttext="0.50 molar N a O H" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.50</mn><mtext> </mtext><mi>M</mi><mtext> </mtext><mtext>Na</mtext><mtext>OH</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> solution. The temperature and <math alttext="the molar concentration of O H with a negative one charge" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mo stretchy="false">[</mo><mtext>O</mtext><msup><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo></mrow></msup><mo stretchy="false">]</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> remain constant throughout the reaction. The results are summarized in the table below.

Time

(<math alttext="in minutes" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>min</mi><mo>⁡</mo></mrow></mstyle></math>)

Absorbance

0
 0.60

4
 0.48

8
 0.38

12
 0.30

16
 0.24

20
 0.19

24
 0.15

(f) Determine the half-life of the reaction. Include units with your answer.

(g) Explain how the absorbance and time data are consistent with a process that is first order with respect to <math alttext="B P B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>BP</mtext><mtext>B</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>.

A second trial is conducted at the same constant temperature, but with <math alttext="the molar concentration of O H with a negative one charge" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mo stretchy="false">[</mo><mtext>O</mtext><msup><mrow><mtext>H</mtext><mtext></mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo></mrow></msup><mo stretchy="false">]</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> changed to <math alttext="2.00 molar" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>2.00</mn><mtext> </mtext><mi>M</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>. The observed half-life of the reaction is shorter than for the first trial when <math alttext="the molar concentration of O H with a negative one charge" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mo stretchy="false">[</mo><mtext>O</mtext><msup><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo></mrow></msup><mo stretchy="false">]</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> was <math alttext="0.50 molar" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.50</mn><mtext> </mtext><mi>M</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>.
(h) Explain, in term of particle collisions, why the half-life of the reaction decreases when <math alttext="the molar concentration of O H with a negative one charge" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mo stretchy="false">[</mo><mtext>O</mtext><msup><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo></mrow></msup><mo stretchy="false">]</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> is changed from <math alttext="0.50 molar" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.50</mn><mtext> </mtext><mi>M</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> to <math alttext="2.00 molar" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>2.00</mn><mtext> </mtext><mi>M</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>.

(i) Is the activation energy for the reaction when <math alttext="the molar concentration of O H with a negative one charge" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mo stretchy="false">[</mo><mtext>O</mtext><msup><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo></mrow></msup><mo stretchy="false">]</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> is <math alttext="2.00 molar" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>2.00</mn><mtext> </mtext><mi>M</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> greater than, the same as, or less than the activation energy when <math alttext="the molar concentration of O H with a negative one charge" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mo stretchy="false">[</mo><mtext>O</mtext><msup><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo></mrow></msup><mo stretchy="false">]</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> is <math alttext="0.50 molar" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.50</mn><mtext> </mtext><mi>M</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>? Justify your answer.

In order to prepare the <math alttext="2.00 molar" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>2.00</mn><mtext> </mtext><mi>M</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> solution of <math alttext="N a O H aqueous" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Na</mtext><mtext>OH</mtext><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math>, one student follows a procedure with the following steps.
Step 1: Measure out <math alttext="16.0 grams" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>16.0</mn><mtext> </mtext><mtext>g</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> of <math alttext="N a O H solid" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Na</mtext><mtext>OH</mtext><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math>.
Step 2: Add the <math alttext="N a O H solid" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Na</mtext><mtext>OH</mtext><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> to a <math alttext="100.0 milliliter" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>100.0</mn><mtext> </mtext><mtext>mL</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> volumetric flask that is half-filled with distilled water.
Step 3: Add enough distilled water to bring the volume up to the line on the flask.
(j) The chemical quantities used in the procedure do NOT produce <math alttext="2.00 molar N a O H aqueous" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mn>2.00</mn><mtext> </mtext><mi>M</mi><mtext> </mtext><mtext>N</mtext><mtext>a</mtext><mtext>O</mtext><mtext>H</mtext><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></math>. Describe specifically how they should be changed in order to produce <math alttext="2.00 molar N a O H aqueous" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mn>2.00</mn><mtext> </mtext><mi>M</mi><mtext> </mtext><mtext>N</mtext><mtext>a</mtext><mtext>O</mtext><mtext>H</mtext><mo>(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></math> .

(k) Another student is preparing a <math alttext="2.00 molar N a O H" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>2.00</mn><mtext> </mtext><mi>M</mi><mtext> </mtext><mtext>Na</mtext><mtext>OH</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> solution using the correct chemical quantities, but notices that some undissolved solid remains at the bottom of the volumetric flask. Is the concentration of <math alttext="N a O H aqueous" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Na</mtext><mtext>OH</mtext><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> in the solution in the flask greater than, less than, or equal to <math alttext="2.00 molar" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>2.00</mn><mtext> </mtext><mi>M</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> ? Explain your answer.

(l) When preparing solutions of <math alttext="N a O H" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>N</mtext><mtext>a</mtext><mtext>O</mtext><mtext>H</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, the student notices that the temperature increases when dissolving <math alttext="N a O H solid" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Na</mtext><mtext>OH</mtext><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> in water. In a separate experiment, the student dissolves <math alttext="1.0 mole" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>1.0</mn><mtext> </mtext><mtext>mol</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> of <math alttext="N a O H solid" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Na</mtext><mtext>OH</mtext><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> in <math alttext="1000 decimal point grams" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>1000.</mn><mtext> </mtext><mtext>g</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> each of two different solvents, X and water. Assuming the magnitude of the enthalpy change is the same regardless of solvent, would the temperature change in X be greater than, less than, or equal to the temperature change in the water? Justify your answer. The specific heat capacities of water and solvent X are given in the table below.
SolventWaterXSpecific Heat Capacity (<math alttext="joules per gram degree Celsius" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>J</mtext><mo>/</mo><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mtext>g</mtext><mo>⋅</mo><mi>°</mi><mtext>C</mtext><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math>)4.182.53

skill.text: 2.C: Identify experimental procedures that are aligned to a scientific question (which may include a sketch of a lab setup).
